clinical_study.brief_title: Study of the Effectiveness of a Polymer Cerclage System Compared to Cerclages Used in Standard Care (CERCPMCF) )
clinical_study.official_title: Outcomes of Adjuvant "Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System" to Manage Prosthetic Rehabilitation, Per Prosthetic or Primary Femoral Fractures. A Prospective, Multicentric, Simple Blind, Comparative, Non-inferiority Study, Compared to Cerclage Systems Used in Standard Care.

brief_summary.textblock:
The use of cerclage wiring in the management of femur fractures is common. With the increase in the placement of total hip prostheses, the occurrence of peri-prosthetic hip fractures is also increasing, notably due to an older population.
Whether it is for a fracture on a native femur or on a periprosthetic hip fracture, the use of cerclage wiring is an adjuvant additional but not the main means to ensure stable osteosynthesis, allowing re-loading and early rehabilitation of patients. This method has demonstrated its ability to improve the fixation of this fracture type, associated with osteosynthesis or hip prosthesis revision surgery. However, metal cerclage expose to a risk of metallosis which can compromise bone fusion, injury to neighboring soft parts causing pain and also injury to the surgical team when handling them. More recently, non-metallic cerclage have been developed and could overcome certain risks associated with metallic cerclage, while ensuring their bone fixing capacity and therefore bone consolidation. Indeed, non-metallic cerclage could withstand similar or even greater stresses than metallic cables, in particular concerning their resistance to rupture.
The "Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System" is a polymer cerclage which has been developed and could be used in these indications.
Thus, this study (SERRE) aims to investigate the clinical results and sequelae of adjuvant cerclage wires "Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System" in the management of prosthetic rehabilitation, per prosthetic or primary femoral fractures compared with cerclages system used in standard care.
SERRE is a 36 months follow up study in two arms :
- Experimental group: "Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System"
- Control group: "cerclages used in standard care" After each surgery, the patient follow-up period is 36 months. with 4 planned consultation visits after surgery at 6-8 weeks, 3, 6 and 36 months, with collection and measurement of the endpoints.
The main objective of this study is to assess the role of "Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System" of COUSIN Biotech in comparison with cerclages (metallic for the majority) used in standard care ; in the optimization of the consolidation of primary and periprosthetic femoral fractures, 6 months after surgery.

study_design_info.masking_description: Single blinded study. The patient will be blinded from the randomization arm. As the procedure is performed under general anaesthesia, the patient will not be informed whether or not the Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System has been implanted as a result of the procedure.

primary_outcome.measure: Assess role of "Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System" of COUSIN Biotech in comparison with cerclages (metallic for the majority) used in standard care; in the optimization of the consolidation of primary and periprosthetic femoral fractures
primary_outcome.description: primary endpoint will be success or failure 6 months after surgery: Success of "Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System" to optimize consolidation during 6 months post surgery is defined as: the ability to walk full weight bearing without pain at the fracture site, and radiographs showing signs of bony union with no rupture or migration of the cerclage. Rupture or cerclage migration or nonunion or need for revision of the implant before 6 months is considered as failure.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assess consolidation rate during 6 months post surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Consolidation (or union) is defined as the ability to walk full weight bearing without pain at the fracture site and radiographs showing signs of bony union. A femur x-ray, also known as femur series or femur radiograph, is a set of two x-rays performed of the entire femur.

Union time is defined as time until ability of patient to walk full weight bearing without pain at the fracture site and radiographs showing signs of bony union. A femur x-ray, also known as femur series or femur radiograph, is a set of two x-rays performed of the entire femur.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assess rupture and migration rate of the cerclage after surgery throughout the follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Rupture and migration of the cerclage are confirmed on X Ray imaging. A femur x-ray, also known as femur series or femur radiograph, is a set of two x-rays performed of the entire femur.
Pain will be assessed using visual analog scale pain scores (VAS) from 0 to 100 (0 means no pain at all and 100 maximum pain) at each visit.

secondary_outcome.measure: To report the incidence of complications and their treatment, particularly with respect to the need of further surgery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the whole study (up to 36 months)]
secondary_outcome.description: Safety data during patients 36 months follow up are defined such as: Infection Neurovascular injury Allergic reaction Bone ischemia Irritation feeling

Surgery characteristics are: Rupture of cerclage during the surgery (at time of implantation) Number of wire cerclages used implant used for osteosynthesis (nail or plate) Using of screw fixation operative time

secondary_outcome.measure: Assess physicians satisfaction regarding the use of "Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System
secondary_outcome.description: Physicians satisfaction regarding the use of "Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System" will be assessed on: Global satisfaction of the surgeon Ease of use Ancillaries (Cable Passer, Tensioner) : ease of use and lightweight Ease of tension control by the surgeon using tensioner Ease of tracking of the cerclage on radiography Resistance over time (at least until bone consolidation)

arm_group.arm_group_label: Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System
arm_group.description: Patients receives Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System
Patients receives cerclages used in standard care"

intervention.intervention_name: Implantation of Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System
intervention.description: implantation of Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System to the patient and follow up for 36 months post-intervention
intervention.arm_group_label: Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System

intervention.intervention_name: Implantation of Cerclage used in current practice
intervention.description: implantation of Cerclage used in current practice to patients and follow up for 36 months post-intervention

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient with primary femoral fractures (diaphyseal, metaphyseal, epiphyseal proximal or distal towards the knee) without joint splitting, with osteosynthesis by plate and screw or osteosynthesis by Intramedullary nailing
- or Patients with traumatic fracture of the femur that required prosthetic rehabilitation
- or Patients with peri-prosthetic fracture of the femur type B or C according to Vancouver classification
- who underwent fixation with cerclage wiring (Sterile Self Locking Polymer Cerclage System or other cerclage systems used in standard care)
- age ≥18 years
- Who have given free, informed and written consent to participate in the study
- Patient able to communicate in French
- Patient affiliated to a social security system or entitled to a social security system
Exclusion Criteria:
- high-energy injury,
- associated damage to other long bones,
- fracture extension to the articular surface with displacement
- Severe disease that could interfere with the study results or be life threatening
- Patients with an infection
- Allergy to any component of the medical products
- Pregnant or breastfeeding women
- Anticipated unavailability during the study
- Participation in a clinical trial within 3 months prior to the inclusion visit.
- Patient with linguistic or psychological incapacity to understand and sign the informed consent.
- Patient deprived of liberty by administrative or judicial decision, or being under guardianship.
